section: ğŸ” Figure Out Your Unfair Advantage
text:
ğŸ” Figure Out Your Unfair Advantage






ğŸ’¡ Unfair advantages are skills, experiences, or resources that give an individual a significant edge over others in achieving success or reaching their goals, often stemming from circumstances beyond their control or exclusive opportunities.

âš ï¸ Donâ€™t skip this step! Itâ€™s extremely important for a long-lasting successful freelancing career.




Your unfair advantage could stem from:


ğŸ‘” Work experience
ğŸ˜Š Personality traits (e.g., compassion, attention to detail, patience)
ğŸ§  Domain expertise (e.g., coding, drawing, woodworking)
ğŸ“š Learning ability

Ibraheemâ€™s Unfair Advantages:

ğŸ” How to Identify Your Unfair Advantage




Reflect on your skills and experiences
Ask friends and family for their perspective
Consider your personality traits and how they might benefit clients
Think about areas where you learn quickly
Read â€œThe Unfair Advantageâ€ by Ash Ali and Hasan Kubba for more insights

title: ğŸš€ Freelancing 101 Cheatsheet
section: ğŸ’¼ Transform Your Unfair Advantage into a Marketable Skill
text:
ğŸ’¼ Transform Your Unfair Advantage into a Marketable Skill
After you figure out your unfair advantage, itâ€™s time to make it into a marketable skill.





graph LR
    A[Unfair Advantage] --> B{Combination}

    B --> E[Very Specialized]
    C --> F[e.g., Software + AI]
    D --> G[e.g., Operations for Chiropractors]

title: ğŸš€ Freelancing 101 Cheatsheet
section: ğŸ¦ Two Birds One Stone: Portfolio and Your First Gig
text:
ğŸ¦ Two Birds One Stone: Portfolio and Your First Gig






ğŸ’¼ Portfolio is everything. Doesnâ€™t matter if you already have lots of work experience on your resume.



Think about these key questions:


ğŸ¤” How do I showcase myself and my unfair advantage?
ğŸ¯ Based on the type of work Iâ€™m going for, how do I show that I have the skills and experience my potential client would want?
â³ Spend a lot of time building your portfolio because that is almost always the first screen








ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: Change your portfolio projects depending on the specific project you are trying to land. Clients will hire the freelancer with the most relevant experience.









âš ï¸ Donâ€™t just do personal projects by yourself! Go out and offer to work on real projects to put on your portfolio.




Sample Portfolio Templates





graph TD
    A[Portfolio Templates] --> B[Template 1]
    A --> C[Template 2]
    A --> D[Template 3]

title: ğŸš€ Freelancing 101 Cheatsheet
text:
ğŸ”§ Platforms






ğŸ’¼ I personally prefer not to use platforms like Fiverr and Upwork as a freelancer because margins are very thin and sometimes people can be difficult to work with. But they can be very beneficial!



Consider using platforms if:

ğŸï¸ You have a completely blank portfolio. Itâ€™s a good way to start building your portfolio.
ğŸš€ You have a rare skill that is in high demand (e.g., building AI chatbots).
ğŸ’° You can undercut peopleâ€™s prices (e.g., building websites like this one using Quarto, which is way faster and cheaper).
ğŸŒ Youâ€™re from a developing country because generally developed country clients pay better than local clients.
ğŸ¤ You just want to expand your network.

title: ğŸš€ Freelancing 101 Cheatsheet
text:
ğŸŒ± Sourcing Clients & Scaling






ğŸ’¼ Initially, you might need to work for free and handle challenging situations. The goal is to build a system that continuously attracts clients, allowing you to be selective.








flowchart LR
    A[Start] --> B[Initial Projects]
    B --> C{Build System}
    C --> D[Manage Relationships]
    C --> E[Outreach]
    D --> F[Repeat Clients]
    D --> G[Referrals]
    E --> H[Attend Events]
    E --> I[Post Content]
    F & G & H & I --> J[Selective Clientele]






Key Strategies: ::: {.emoji-list}
ğŸ¤ Manage Current Relationships
Deliver excellent work Foster repeat business Encourage referrals
ğŸ“¢ Outreach
ğŸ­ Attend industry events (e.g., content creator meetups) ğŸ–‹ï¸ Post educational content online (especially on LinkedIn) :::






ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: At events, youâ€™ll meet potential clients like fractional operations companies, editors, investors, and lawyers. The networking opportunities are invaluable!









âš ï¸ Caution: Building a robust client network takes time, but itâ€™s worth the effort. Eventually, youâ€™ll have the luxury of choosing your clients.

title: ğŸš€ Freelancing 101 Cheatsheet
text:
â˜ï¸ All The Other Tips
ğŸ¢ Setting up a Company






In the US, consider an LLC; in Canada, a C-corp. These structures offer legal protection and tax benefits. âš ï¸ But remember: Donâ€™t get bogged down with this initially. Focus on landing your first client!



ğŸ’° Pricing ::: {.callout .tip}
In the beginning, getting paid at all is a win. As you gain experience, align with industry standards. Donâ€™t underprice your services.
ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: Ask clients for their budget first to gauge expectations. ::: ::: {.book} ğŸ“š Recommended Read: â€œNever Split the Differenceâ€ by Chris Voss ::: ğŸ” Prevent Scope Creep ::: {.callout .warning} Clearly define:
What you will and wonâ€™t do Level of post-project support (e.g., tech support)
This clarity makes it easier to maintain boundaries later. ::: ğŸŒŸ Reputation Management ::: {.callout} Remember: Your reputation is everything in freelancing. ğŸ”‘ Key Strategy: Underpromise and overdeliver :::
